questions.prompt: Which quality allows a distributed system to keep operating even if one node crashes?
questions.explanation: Fault tolerance is the system’s ability to survive a node failure without downtime.

questions.prompt: How does role-based access control (RBAC) assign permissions?
questions.explanation: RBAC groups permissions under roles so that granting or removing a role updates a user’s effective access.

options.label: Permissions are tied to roles, and users inherit them by joining a role.
Permissions are granted directly to every individual user account.
Permissions are embedded in each hardware device.
Permissions are randomly rotated among logged-in users.

questions.prompt: What is an advantage of designing services around bounded contexts?
questions.explanation: Bounded contexts encapsulate models so changes remain localized and do not ripple through unrelated areas.

options.label: Changes stay inside a domain boundary, reducing the blast radius across other services.
Every service must share a single database.
Deployments must be synchronized for all services at once.

questions.prompt: Which trio of metrics defines the RED (Rate, Errors, Duration) method?

options.label: Request rate, error count, and request duration.
Request rate, error count, and saturation.
CPU usage, memory usage, and duration.
Latency percentile, throughput, and packet loss.

questions.explanation: The RED method tracks how many requests arrive, how many fail, and how long they take.

questions.prompt: Which automation pattern pushes code changes to production progressively with guardrails?
questions.explanation: Canarying exposes a small percentage of traffic first to reduce risk.

questions.prompt: Which numeric pair best captures service level objectives?

options.label: Mean time to recovery and budget
Target reliability percentage and measurement window
Cost of goods sold and margin

questions.explanation: An SLO pairs a reliability target with the period the target is evaluated against.

questions.prompt: Which XML snippet correctly represents <t> Alan and Mairi. dreamed. using the <t> tag?
questions.explanation: The <t> tag must wrap the entire expression and include the dreamed verb, making the second snippet the valid representation.

questions.prompt: An XML document has a tree structure. It:

options.label: can have multiple roots and multiple leaves
can have multiple roots or records

questions.explanation: Every well-formed XML document has exactly one root element, while leaves are unconstrained.

questions.prompt: Which statement captures the well-formedness requirements for XML?

options.label: It must have a single root element and every tag pair must be properly nested.
It cannot contain whitespace in any text node.
It must only use tags defined by the W3C core schema.
It may have multiple roots as long as there is one leaf.

questions.explanation: Well-formed XML requires exactly one root element with every element opened and closed in the correct order.

questions.prompt: Before writing nodes with XmlTextWriter, which method call is required to properly format the output file?
questions.explanation: WriteStartDocument writes the XML declaration and prepares the writer for subsequent nodes.

questions.prompt: In the XmlTextReader loop shown, how is the XML data processed?
questions.explanation: XmlTextReader is a streaming API, so the sample reads node-by-node rather than materializing the full DOM.

options.label: It reads one node at a time without building an in-memory tree.
It loads the entire XML document into a DOM before the loop starts.
It buffers only attributes while skipping elements.
It writes the nodes back to disk as it parses them.

questions.prompt: In the same XmlTextReader snippet, which line is the only one that loads a node into memory?
questions.explanation: According to the quiz key, the equality check at line (5) is where the desired element is realized for processing.

questions.prompt: If the XmlTextReader code calls reader.MoveToAttribute("author") after Read(), must the node have attributes?
questions.explanation: MoveToAttribute returns false if the attribute is missing; the call itself does not require attributes to exist.

options.label: The call throws because the node must have attributes.
The call simply returns false when the attribute is missing.
The reader rewinds to the previous node before continuing.
The reader automatically adds a blank author attribute.

questions.prompt: How are functions used within an XPath expression?
questions.explanation: XPath functions are embedded within the expression to evaluate nodes or values; there is no trailing function-call syntax.

options.label: They must appear only at the end of the expression after the final node step.
They are invoked within the expression, such as contains() or count(), to filter or compute values.
They can only be used in attribute predicates.
XPath does not support any function calls.

questions.prompt: Which XML processing model reads one node into memory at a time based on a path expression?
questions.explanation: SAX is an event-driven, streaming API that pulls in a single node at a time.

questions.prompt: What is an advantage of a server-side solution for displaying an XML file in a required format?

options.label: No need to write an XSL style sheet
No special requirement on the Web browser

questions.explanation: Rendering on the server removes browser requirements, so any client can consume the result.

questions.prompt: If your ASP.NET app creates an XML file, where should it be stored within the application domain?
questions.explanation: App_Data is the designated location for data files such as XML generated by the app.

questions.prompt: Which of the following terms is NOT defined in the W3C namespace http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema?
questions.explanation: Elements such as all, complexType, schema, and choice live in the XML Schema namespace; cc:core does not.

questions.prompt: A Document Type Definition (DTD) file:

options.label: defines the syntax of an XML file
defines the structure of an XML schema file
extends the XML schema with more data types

questions.explanation: A DTD declares the legal structure and elements for an XML document.

questions.prompt: Which description best matches an empty XML element?

options.label: An element with no text content or child nodes, often written with a self-closing tag.
Any element that lacks attributes but has children.
An element that contains whitespace-only text nodes.
An element defined outside of the namespace scope.

questions.explanation: Empty elements do not wrap any text or children and can be written using the self-closing syntax.

questions.prompt: What XML processing model reads one node into memory at a time?
questions.explanation: SAX parsers stream XML, delivering one node at a time through events.

questions.prompt: What does a Document Type Definition (DTD) file define?

options.label: The syntax of another DTD file
The structure and legal elements/attributes of an XML document
Extensions to the C# base class library

questions.explanation: A DTD constrains how an XML document is structured by listing its allowed element tree.

questions.prompt: Given the DTD declaration `<!ELEMENT instructor (name?, officeHours?, officeHour?, phone?, email?)>`, which child element is required?
questions.explanation: Only `email` lacks the question mark, so it must appear exactly once.

questions.prompt: In the declaration `<!ELEMENT instructor (name?, email?, officeHours?, phone?, email?)>`, what does the final `email` entry imply?

options.label: The entire instructor element is optional

questions.explanation: Repeating `email` without `?` forces at least one appearance of that element.

questions.prompt: Why was XML Schema introduced after DTDs?

options.label: DTDs already supported every data type
XML Schema adds strong data typing and reuses XML syntax
DTDs were too fast to parse
XML Schema is required for JSON documents

questions.explanation: XSD addressed DTD limitations by allowing typed validation and representing the schema itself as XML.

questions.prompt: Which language natively supports data types such as integer?
questions.explanation: XSD supports typed elements (integer, decimal, etc.) whereas DTD sticks to text.

questions.prompt: When working with `XmlSchemaSet` for validation, what can you load into the set?

options.label: Multiple XML documents along with one or more schema files

questions.explanation: `XmlSchemaSet` aggregates schemas and XML documents so you can validate many files in one pass.

questions.prompt: Which statement best describes the expressive power of XSLT?

options.label: It only formats text and cannot branch.
It can express loops and conditionals, making it effectively Turing complete.
It can only run on the server.

questions.explanation: XSLT templates can branch and iterate, giving the language full programming expressiveness.

questions.prompt: What is Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) used for?

options.label: It is an XML-based language that defines style/transform rules for converting XML into other XML/HTML.
It stores binary blobs inside XML.
It is a JSON templating language.
It is an XSLT processor embedded in hardware.

questions.explanation: XSL stylesheets describe how to transform an XML document—often into HTML or another XML schema.

questions.prompt: Which document types can Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) style?
questions.explanation: CSS is primarily applied to markup languages such as HTML and XML.

questions.prompt: What is XHTML?

options.label: Extensible HTML defined via a DTD so it can be parsed as XML.
A deprecated HTML version with no DTD.
A new XML format for XSLT processors.

questions.explanation: XHTML combines HTML semantics with XML rules, using a DTD to define the markup.

questions.prompt: HTML 5.0 is based on which foundational technology?
questions.explanation: Per the provided notes, HTML5 builds on the CGI-driven web stack.

questions.prompt: ASPX GUI design primarily relies on which components?
questions.explanation: ASPX pages mix HTML controls with server-side controls for dynamic rendering.

questions.prompt: What is a drawback of transforming XML to HTML in the browser?

options.label: The client must install the .NET Framework
You must rely on the browser shipping an XSLT processor and author the XSL stylesheet
The XML file must be rewritten

questions.explanation: Client-side transforms require browsers with XSLT support plus custom XSL stylesheets.

questions.prompt: What language is used to extend new elements in HTML5?
questions.explanation: HTML5 leverages DTDs to define and extend permissible tags.

questions.prompt: XHTML (Extensible HTML) is defined by which specification?
questions.explanation: XHTML documents are governed by a DTD so they remain valid XML.

questions.prompt: Which practice best ensures that cross-team service contracts stay reliable as systems evolve?

options.label: Let each team change APIs without notifying consumers.
Adopt versioned contracts with automated contract tests shared across producers and consumers.
Freeze API designs forever once released.
Rely on manual email approvals before every deployment.

questions.explanation: Versioned contracts plus automated contract testing keep teams aligned while still allowing services to evolve safely.
